issues.description: The solution implementation declares the class fields using snake_case identifiers (e.g. lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, etc.) but the constructor, getters/setters and other methods use camelCase identifiers (e.g. lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, etc.) as specified in the problem statement. The problem statement / UML also expects camelCase attribute names. This mismatch of attribute identifiers in the solution makes the code uncompilable and will confuse students about the correct field names to implement/use.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the field identifiers consistent with the problem statement and the rest of the code. Change the field declarations in the solution to use the camelCase names specified in the UML: lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors — or alternatively update all usages to match the declared snake_case names. Prefer keeping camelCase to match the problem statement and Java naming conventions. Ensure constructor assignments and all getters/setters reference the same field names.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the UML) refer to attributes using camelCase names (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). In the solution implementation the fields are declared using snake_case (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) but all constructor parameters, assignments and accessor methods use camelCase identifiers (e.g., this.lectureName, getLectureName()). This mismatch between declared field names and the names used elsewhere will confuse students and even cause compilation errors in the solution. It creates a direct mapping problem between the UML/problem description, the template placeholder for attributes, and the provided solution code.
